topic.title: Certificate management in Couchbase
topic.shortdesc: This section explains how to configure an X.509 certificate for Couchbase Server.

body.note: Choosing a root CA, the CA hierarchy, and obtaining a certificate from that CA chain to set up a Couchbase cluster are not within the scope of this document.

section.title: Setting up Couchbase cluster and node certificates
section.p: The Couchbase cluster certificate must be signed by the root CA, directly or via an intermediate CA. Generate a Couchbase cluster certificate manually, without using an automated certificate signing request.

The Couchbase cluster certificate is then used to sign a Couchbase node certificate, which contains the following:
The node private key, or the server.key
The node certificate or the server.pem
The certificate chain file based on the supported CA hierarchy or cacert.pem
To set a certificate path use this command: cat intermediate_ca_cert.pem root_ca.pem > > cacert.pem
Only full Couchbase administrators can generate Couchbase cluster and node certificates.

section.title: Enabling CA authentication
section.p: Couchbase Server uses a cluster-wide configuration option called enable-servercaauth to enable CA authentication.

The full Couchbase administrators can use this CLI command, which is by default false or turned off, to enable CA-based authentication only in cases when all nodes in a cluster have been upgraded to the latest release that supports this feature.
In cases when some of the nodes are not upgraded to the latest release, Couchbase administrators will use self-signed certificates as before.

section.title: Certificate rotation
section.p: Rotate a certificate when it expires or a widespread breach occurs.
section.note: Couchbase administrators should manually pre-install all client machines with the root CA public keys before rotating server certificates. The server will send the certificate chain to the client, which will then validate the chain using the root public key.

dlentry.dt: Rotation of the intermediate CA certificate
dlentry.dd: Only the intermediate certificate is rotated, and the root certificate is unchanged. For new connections only, the server sends the certificate chain with the new intermediate certificate. This new certificate gets verified by the client, and the connection is re-established.

dlentry.dt: Rotation of the root CA certificate
dlentry.dd: In this case, the Couchbase administrators will manually push the new root CA certificate to a local path on all the nodes and start configuring Couchbase server with the new CA certificate.
